title: Mitsuwa Marketplace
text:
is a <a href="Asian%20supermarket">Japanese supermarket</a> chain in America, with locations in <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>, and <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>.
History.
As a subsidiary of <a href="Yaohan">Yaohan</a>, "Yaohan USA" opened its first supermarket in <a href="Fresno%2C%20California">Fresno</a> in 1979. During its heyday, Yaohan operated eight stores all over the States, as well as four Daikichi sushi shops. 
Upon bankruptcy of Yaohan in 1997, Yaohan USA was subject to a <a href="management%20buyout">management buyout</a> by regional management, with rebranding as "Mitsuwa Marketplace". 
Mitsuwa continued to expand its stores, mainly inside California. In December 2012, , a Japanese trading company, acquired Mitsuwa's stock.
Store locations.
California.
Mitsuwa has seven stores in four metropolitan areas in <a href="California">California</a>:
The Los Angeles location of Mitsuwa Marketplace in the Little Tokyo neighborhood closed in 2009. In 2019, Torrance closed their previous location in the Old Town Torrance. The new Torrance location within the <a href="Del%20Amo%20Fashion%20Center">Del Amo Fashion Center</a> opened in February 2020.
Hawaii.
The second-floor Honolulu store is located in the <a href="International%20Market%20Place">International Market Place</a> in <a href="Waikiki">Waikiki</a>, <a href="Honolulu">Honolulu</a>.
Texas.
Mitsuwa entered the Dallas/Fort Worth area with a store in Plano, an upper-middle-class northern suburb of <a href="Dallas">Dallas</a>. The store, which opened in the spring of 2017, is near North Central Expressway and Legacy Drive.
Chicago metropolitan area.
The <a href="Chicago%20area">Chicago area</a> store is at 100 E. Algonquin Road in <a href="Arlington%20Heights%2C%20Illinois">Arlington Heights</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a> — part of a number of Japanese businesses in Arlington Heights — and opened in 1991. The store is open 365 days a year from 9 am to 9 pm. Mitsuwa is the largest Japanese marketplace in the <a href="Midwestern%20US">Midwestern US</a>. The Chicago store is one of three that are east of the Rockies. This Mitsuwa location, like those in other states, was formerly known as <a href="Yaohan">Yaohan</a>.
The food court has many traditional foods, such as <a href="sushi">sushi</a>, <a href="tempura">tempura</a>, noodles, etc. It is made of the Otafuku-tei (now replaced by Gabutto Burger), Kayaba, <a href="Hokkaido_Ramen_Santouka">Santouka Ramen</a>, Releaf Matcha, Jockey Express, Daikichi Sushi, Pastry House Hippo, and Mama House restaurants. Mitsuwa hosts the JTB <a href="travel%20agency">travel agency</a>. There are two entertainment shops in Mitsuwa Chicago, JBC Video, a Japanese video rental store, and <a href="Books%20Kinokuniya">Kinokuniya</a>, a Japanese book shop that sells stationery, novels, <a href="manga">manga</a>, and other imported media. A <a href="cell%20phone">cell phone</a> store, Galaxy Wireless, is at the Chicago Mitsuwa.
Mitsuwa Chicago had a <a href="Dishware">china</a> store called 'Utsuwa no Yakata'. This store closed on April 1, 2006. Kinokuniya bookstore, which had expanded into the area previously owned by a China store, has been replaced by SanSeiDo.
The location has two personal care shops, <a href="Shiseido">Shiseido</a>, a Japanese cosmetics store, and Super Health, a vitamin and other health supplement store.
New Jersey.
The <a href="Edgewater%2C%20New%20Jersey">Edgewater</a>, <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a> store is located on 595 River Road. It has a <a href="food%20court">food court</a>, a <a href="bookstore">bookstore</a> owned by <a href="Kinokuniya">Kinokuniya</a>, a gift shop selling <a href="Bape">Bape</a> clothing and <a href="golf%20club%20%28equipment%29">golf clubs</a>, a <a href="video%20store">video store</a> that carries <a href="DVD">DVD</a>s and <a href="Laserdisc">Laserdisc</a>s of movies and a store selling <a href="Japanese%20ceramics">Japanese ceramics</a> and <a href="rice%20cooker">denki-gama</a>, making Mitsuwa more of a mini-<a href="Shopping%20mall">mall</a> than a traditional supermarket. It is a small taste of what current Japanese multi-story malls, or subway stations, are like.
The supermarket section sells fresh produce and certified <a href="Angus%20beef">Angus beef</a>, as well as Japanese drinks and snacks such as <a href="Yakult">Yakult</a>, <a href="Calpis">Calpis</a>, <a href="Ramune">Ramune</a>, <a href="Ikechi%20Shrimp%20Chip">Ikechi Shrimp Chip</a>s, <a href="Pocari%20Sweat">Pocari Sweat</a>, <a href="Pocky">Pocky</a>, <a href="Pretz">Pretz</a>, and Japanese liquor such as <a href="Sake">Sake</a> and <a href="Sh%C5%8Dch%C5%AB">Shōchū</a>.
The <a href="Books%20Kinokuniya">Books Kinokuniya</a> bookstore section sells Japanese music CDs, novels, job applications, children's books, manga, and imported magazines (including dozens of <a href="Japanese%20fashion">Japanese</a> <a href="fashion%20magazine">fashion magazine</a>s) such as <a href="Weekly%20Shonen%20Jump">Weekly Shonen Jump</a> and <a href="Disney%20Fan">Disney Fan</a>.
There is also a kiosk that sells <a href="Ito%20En">Ito En</a> tea and Minamoto Kitchoan that sells Japanese sweets such as <a href="manju%20%28confection%29">manju</a>, <a href="mochi">mochi</a>, and Inja.
A <a href="Daiso">Daiso</a> "<a href="100-yen%20shop">100-yen shop</a>" location opened at the marketplace in August 2019.
The New Jersey location used to run an exclusive <a href="shuttle%20bus">shuttle bus</a> between the store and the <a href="Port%20Authority%20Bus%20Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>. The bus transported Mitsuwa customers for a nominal fee and it did not make any stops along its route. The service was terminated December 31, 2014.
